content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solvable in 5 min, but not for the average CoC player
Really enjoyable, had fun!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's fun.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I see you have added equations on how to solve.
I pre-approve.

TBH
"which is equal to the square root of -1" 
can be confusing for some people.
I'd just put: 
"i represents the imaginary unit, its square equals -1"

The only tiny questionable thing here is that you may consider making it a bit easier to solve it without a built-in complex function.

I like this idea, looks fun to solve.

However, I think it's best to completely solve the algebra for the square of the complex number you describe. Some users may not know that i^2 = -1 and this could make the problem very hard for them.

(a + bi)^2 = a^2 + (2*a*b)i + (bi)^2 = (a^2-b^2) + (2*a*b)i

^ Simple edit that makes it easier for people who haven't studied complex numbers before.

Parsing complex number is difficult in language which doesn't have a built-in function to do it (ruby is an exception, you can't do it that easily in a lot of other languages).
As others have already suggested you should add spaces around the middle + or - that would make it easier (and fairer for those who don't use ruby).
In the actual state, the parsing make it too hard for a clash of code (take too much time).
Add a space around the middle + or - sign and I think it could become solvable in under 5 minutes on most languages. Otherwise it takes too long to complete for me, like 10 minutes.

The problem looks much better since you added the equations. Even so, I think most of the 15 minutes would be spent trying to figure out how to parse each number (for languages that don't support parsing something like 1+2i into a complex number).

It's true that it's easy enough to grab (1) and (2) out of 1+2i, but if it's (-35) and (-3), it suddenly becomes much harder. The best I can think of is searching for the last index of either (+) or (-) and then splitting from that index. You could make the problem go much faster by adding spaces around the operand (-5 - 3i), though perhaps it's still okay to stick with the current format.

Grammar-wise, there are several missing "the"s:
* "The symbol i represents the imaginary unit which is the square root of -1."
* "The sum of two complex numbers..."
* "The square of a complex number..."
* "If either the real or the imaginary part is 0, it should still be printed." (Input and Output sections)
Also rewrite: "For example, the sum of the complex numbers 0+1i, -2-3i, and 4+5i is"

I have to spend 2~3 minutes to google to locate two equations for calculating complex number addition and multiplication.
To make it fairer for coders (like me) who are not good at advanced maths, it is better to have the equation included in statement.
Your examples are not helpful at all. Use variable instead e.g. 
(a+bi) + (c+di) = (a+c) + (b+d)i

Example solution uses Ruby's built-in Complex data type but I didn't find it too hard to do without using built-in data types. Without using imaginary numbers Python solution took me about 8 minutes and even with my very rusty C++ I could get 100% in about 12 minutes (both times include reading the statement).
It's my first submission - let me know if anything can be improved or should be done differently!

so you tell that :
- in ruby there is built-in that permit to solve in 1 minute max
- in other it took you 8 minutes knowing the problem

i see 2 problems :
- it is unfair
- 8 minutes while CoC should be solvable in less than 5 minutes

imho it is more a puzzle than a CoC

Thank you, that's good feedback! I didn't consider it might not be obvious to everyone that you can treat imaginary unit like any other variable. I added equations with variables, hopefully it's more clear now!

I fixed the the issues. I debated adding spaces but I don't think it would really help much. It's simple enough to look for first "+" or "-" starting from second index. Also there are plenty of clashes that you can solve with a simple split already, so I felt like making it a bit different is good.

I kind of disagree. I don't think adding space would help much as it's really simple to parse in any language already:
Easy way to parse it in C: https://hastebin.com/kutunaface.c
Different but still easy way to parse it, in Python: https://hastebin.com/odohejarox.py
Yet another easy way to parse it, in JS: https://hastebin.com/tubuyejama.js
And one more, this time in Kotlin: https://hastebin.com/kiyoqiboso.kt

"the square root of -1" was already in bold font in the statement, but I did end up adding the simplified form of the equation. My worry is that this problem is getting reeeaaally watered down now and it might become mostly a "copy a mathematical equation from the statement into code", which is not a very interesting or educational type of clash. :\

I get where you're coming from, but it's already a reasonably hard clash to solve in <10 minutes. I just practiced it and it took me 8 minutes, even with the headstart I got from having read the instructions beforehand.
I think the full equations just make it more approachable.

The python parsing you show is a pain, tbh.
I think it would be better to do
if "+" in complexnum:
 a,b=complexnum.split("+")
if "-" in complexnum:
 a,b=complexnum.split("-")

But the point is that it's hard enough to solve the parsing problem that Ruby users will have a significant advantage over Python, C#, JS etc.

Adding spaces doesn't make it any harder in Python (.split(" + ")) but it might level the playing field a bit, and Python users can just do (.split()) and then use the middle string of the split to determine the sign, rather than use if-statements.

I think your suggestion makes it more complicated because you'll need additional logic to deal with
>>> "-3-2i".split("-")
['', '3', '2i']

Ruby users will have a significant advantage in most clashes, it's unavoidable :-)
(although in this case Python does have a built-in complex number type as well, so you could also do it the same way as with Ruby: https://hastebin.com/esevipeniv.py )

While adding spaces would make that particular way of solving the parsing part of the problem slightly easier it would also make others slightly harder (such as the ones in JS and Python examples in my previous comment). I think without spaces is the more natural way to express complex numbers (if you were to run into complex numbers to parse it's unlikely they'd have spaces), so I would need to hear a stronger argument for them before making changes.

I think most languages have a built-in type for imaginary numbers (I know at least Python and C++ do) and using those it should be easily doable in less than 5 minutes. Given that you get 15 minutes to solve I think 8-12 minutes (probably way less if you're good) for doing it the "hard" way is reasonable.

That said, it would be helpful if you could try it and tell me how long it took (it's hard to test myself as I am already familiar with the problem).

Took me 14 min to do in python, 8-9 min to figure out how to do the manual string splitting.  Apparently my slow speed means I'm not a "good" CoC player but I feel like the average CoC player won't solve this problem in 15 min. I'm approving this problem because I don't think the difficulty of this problem is a valid reason to not approve a clash; additionally, CoC seems to know when a problem is hard and selects easier problems if the person is ranked lower.
